Introduction

The Caesar cipher (aka the shift cipher) is a simple and widely known encryption technique. It was invented by Julius Caesar during times of the Roman Empire for confidential military communications. It works as a substitution cipher, where each letter in the alphabet is replaced by another letter located a fixed number of positions down the alphabet (which wraps around itself). For example, if the key was 3 and the shift direction was to the right, the letter B would be replaced with E.

How to use

Type in the text to be encrypted/decrypted below, and the result will be displayed in real time, similar to how Google Translate acts. For the encryption function, the settings you can change are the key and the direction of the shift (default set to 3 and right respectively). For decryption, both left shift and right shift results will be displayed.

Key

Select the number of positions the letters in your text will be shifted over.

Function

Using your chosen key, select whether to encrypt or decrypt your text.

Direction

Select the direction of the shift to be used in encryption.

The code for this project can be found at: https://github.com/cdonougherlee/caesarcipher
